Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Collaborative Research: Versatile Locomotion: From Walking to Dexterous Climbing with a Human-Scale Robot

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project aims to give legged robots the skills to navigate a wide variety of terrain. This capability is needed to employ robots in applications such as search-and-rescue, construction, and exploration of remote environments on Earth and other planets. The multidisciplinary team, composed of researchers at Duke, Stanford, UC Santa Barbara, JPL, and Motiv Robotics, will develop a robot to climb a variety of surfaces ranging from flat ground to overhanging cliffs. Using an array of sensors, unique hands, and sophisticated algorithms, the robot will dynamically adopt walking, crawling, climbing, and swinging strategies to traverse wildly varied terrain. During the course of this research, the team hopes to achieve the milestone of the first demonstration of a human-scale rock climbing robot. The research is also expected to lead to insights into cognitive and biomechanical processes in human and animal locomotion.

Although rock climbing serves as an ideal proving ground for the work, this project conducts basic research to address more a general-purpose goal; namely, to provide the physical and cognitive skills for robots to adaptively navigate varied terrain. It takes a dexterous climbing approach, which uses non-gaited, coordinated sequences of contact to move the body, much as dexterous manipulation uses contact with the fingers and palm to move an object. It will apply principles from optimization, machine learning, bioinspiration, and control theory to make intellectual contributions in several domains, such as robot hand design, planning algorithms, balance strategies, and locomotion performance measurement. Novel grippers, sensor-based planning strategies, reactive maneuvers, and locomotion metrics will be developed during the course of this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Versatile Locomotion project is to investigate how to provide legged robots with the decision-making necessary to be able to traverse very rough and steep terrain. In such terrains, a robot faces a difficult task: how should it step, grab, and shift its body to move toward its goal while avoiding slipping or falling? The project is inspired by the sport of rock climbing, where human climbers must exercise both their intellectual and physical skills to be able to solve challenging routes. In conjunction with collaborators at Stanford University and UC Santa Barbara, the Duke team aimed to provide the Robosimian quadruped robot, which was originally developed by Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL), with the perception and planning capabilities to traverse any terrain from flat ground to steep rock walls. This research could enable diverse robotic applications including search and rescue and extraterrestrial exploration.

The research conducted by the Duke team addressed four problems: a) enabling the robot to choose hold locations for hooks, as well as a novel microspine gripper developed by the Stanford team and specialized for climbing, b) simulation of movement on gravel and sand, c) using a sense of touch to feel for unseen holds, and to ensure that a hold is securely grasped before attempting to put weight on it, and d) preventing and recovering from a fall in uneven terrains. These were tested both in simulation and on the real robot hardware. Although the project fell short of the ambitious ultimate goal of enabling the Robosimian to climb rock walls (largely due to hardware issues) the algorithms developed in this project overcame some of the key technical bottlenecks holding back legged robots from being able to navigate in extreme terrains. The team will continue in the upcoming years to use the software and hardware systems developed in this project to make progress toward the vision of versatile locomotion.
